speaker: tatiana
utterance: You know what? The worst in this illness is that you feel helpless. You feel so very helpless. You know that this boy will die little by little every day in front of your eyes, and you can't do anything. It makes you furious. From time to time, you're furious. You're saying, why? Well, I want to do something about that. I can't just watch it happening like that. This is the only, our chance, and the last one.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: Tatiana hadn't believed in any of this stuff before Alexander got sick. But her and Ed were willing to try anything. The doctors had told them that the muscles would just deteriorate until, at age 18 or so, your heart just can no longer even beat, and he'd die. This is Alexander. He's 10.

speaker: alexander
utterance: Well, the entities, they told us positive concentration. So we're working on that. We're doing our best.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: What's that?

speaker: alexander
utterance: We're doing our best.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: Have they told you that you will be healed?

speaker: alexander
utterance: Yes, they said a couple of times, he will walk. And then he said another time, you will walk very soon. What soon is for the entities, we don't know.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: To me, when I meet people like this, hoping for a miracle, it's really the only choice you have. It seems completely sane to me. It's the logical choice.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: One night, one of the posadas hired an accordion player and had a little dance. And everyone was there. Maggie, she's blind, and she's dancing with Dennis. Gregor, who uses a walker at home, but he gets up and twirls for a second with Cynthia. Then he topples over again. I mean, everyone who's here, they are so joyful just being together and having hope. And whether or not you believe in the spirits and everything, it just seems like it's good for you. It improves your health to be in a beautiful place.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: There was 25 people in my mom's group. No one was cured, but everyone was glad that they'd been there.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Everybody, that is, but you?

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: Right. It wasn't quite enough for me. I mean, my mom still's deaf, my skin's still messed up, and Joao told both of us we needed to come back for more visits. And the worst thing was, my mom and I, we were not seeing eye to eye.

speaker: barbara
utterance: The thing is, can you open your heart to the possibility that this is real, and that in three or four years you could be healed if you do what you need to do? Do you know what I mean?

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: Kind of, but I just think you and I see the world differently.

speaker: barbara
utterance: We probably do. We're two different people. I used to see the world the way you do and I've learned some things by banging my head against the wall and then stopping because I realized it wasn't getting me anywhere.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: I'm not banging my head. I don't think there is a master plan. I don't think there is a reason for everything. I think there are accidents and coincidences.

speaker: barbara
utterance: I don't. And I'm not going to argue that one with you. I don't know, Davy. I would hope that you can just say, let's see what happens.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: I don't want to let you down, but I don't think I'm going to come back here unless it's to visit you because you've moved here or something.

speaker: barbara
utterance: You don't think you would come back even though he says he can cure you? That's up to you. That's entirely up to you. That's hard for me to understand why.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: I don't really believe in it.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: That was the first time I had ever told her that, and maybe realized it myself. I don't know what that means exactly for me and my mom.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: You mean, for the two of you who are so close to say, we disagree on something that's so fundamental and such a big part of her life?

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: Right, because it is everything to her. It's been a couple months since we got back, and she says that she's experiencing some changes. And other people from the group, Maggie, who was blind is saying she's beginning to see a little bit. For my mom, it's the same thing. She says she can feel her inner ears. She can feel changes, shifts, vibrations, and she thinks it's the beginning of hearing.

speaker: barbara
utterance: I can feel my voice going up and down. Suddenly, I have some sense of where the notes are. It's completely different.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: Do you hear the difference?

speaker: barbara
utterance: It's like hearing. It's just vibration. I'm hearing it. I've got to get the tunes, the notes. [SINGING] Amazing grace, how sweet the sound, that saved a soul like me. [END SINGING]

speaker: barbara
utterance: Am I way off? Am I better than I was before?

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: It sounded beautiful to me.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Davy Rothbart is about to head out on a 126-city tour for his new book of excerpts from Found magazine, the magazine he created. Details are at foundmagazine.com.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Coming up, summoning the mysterious entities known as the Food and Drug Administration. That's in a minute, from Chicago Public Radio and Public Radio International, when our program continues.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's This American Life, I'm Ira Glass. Each week on our program, of course, we choose some theme, bring you a variety of different kinds of stories on that theme. Today's program, Miracle Cures. Stories of kids doing whatever they think it might take, doing the impossible to help their parents get cured. We've arrived at Act Two of our program. Act Two is this.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Julia Whitty's dad had cancer, and he had used up all the available kinds of treatment. He probably just had a few months left to live. But there was one hope for him, one last drug that might work. And the problem was, a year of this drug would cost him $47,000, which his insurance couldn't cover and which he could not afford.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So Julia Whitty, she just wrote a magazine article about this experience. She said that she found when she tried to find this drug for him, she found that most of the ways she could get the drug for less were not exactly legal.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: I absolutely was willing to break the law and I can't imagine too many people who wouldn't be, in all honesty. If you clearly saw there was a source for what you needed, and if you had to break the law a little bit to cross over the line to go there and get it, I think most people would do that for somebody that they loved. So that was where I began to look around and see if there was some other way we could get this drug.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So you started looking around, what'd you find?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: I went on the internet, as most people would in this day and age, I just started surfing around. And I did find-- that's where I first came in contact with people who might have had a loved one who died and had leftover prescription that they would sometimes give away or sell. But obviously, we needed a steady, reliable, long-term dose of this stuff. And I eventually was able to locate a country that manufactured this drug for completely different diseases. And they were selling it for about $1,200 a year, which obviously started to sound really cheap.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: As compared with $47,000 per year?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Exactly.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So you go, you fly to some foreign country, you get some doctor there, I guess, to prescribe the drug?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Right, which is not difficult to do in other countries. It's pretty much not difficult to do in any country if you're a traveler.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Did you have to actually claim that you had a disease or did you just tell the doctor, here's my situation.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: I told him the truth regarding my father. And he was more than willing. I think he felt good being able to help me.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And at this point, you're not exactly sure if it's legal to bring these back?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: That's right.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So what do you do?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Well, I had thought about it in advance, because I travel in my adult life and I've spent a lot of time in third world countries and stuff. And I usually travel with a pretty hefty medical arsenal. You know, I'd put multiple pills in one bottle. So I thought, well, I'm just going to go there. However they come, I'm going to take them out of that packaging and put them in empty prescription bottles that I have with other prescription names on them. And in all my years of traveling, I've never come back into the US and had anybody open my bottles. So I really didn't think I was going to have trouble with this.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And so this is like, dozens of pills or hundreds of pills?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: It was somewhere between two-, three-, or four-month supply, enough to sort of start my father on it, do a set of scans and see whether or not it was working.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So you have hundreds of pills, what was the moment like when you finally were coming back into the country?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Well, you definitely get that sweaty palms thing going. You wonder, what are they looking for? What expression on your face? You know you're doing something that could be wrong.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And what do we know about how many people are actually going overseas and bringing back drugs?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: I know that their estimates right now are that between one and two million Americans are getting drugs one way or another from Canada alone.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And is that legal or is that illegal?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: In my personal experience, it was probably always illegal, but it wasn't enforced. For whatever reason, it began to be enforced around December of 2002. And I was told by the FDA that they were cracking down at that point.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Do you know what the penalty would have been if you'd been caught?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: I don't know, but I remember being so angry at the time that I was perfectly prepared to go to jail. Not that I want to go to jail, but I was just feeling this was an absurd way to have to live. And it was ridiculous, in light of the fact that this drug could be had more inexpensively and why my father couldn't have access to it. I considered it immoral.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Now, at some point you learned that you might be able to simply order the drug from, what was it, an online manufacturer? Like an online pharmacy?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Not an online pharmacy. That would have been easy. It was the actual manufacturer in this country overseas. And they claimed they were already doing it for other patients in the United States. And they told me it would just sail through US customs and that did not turn out to be the case. It gets held up in US customs in Cincinnati and I began a long series of conversations with FDA officials, sort of case officers. And they tell me, it's illegal. You can't bring this in.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And the reason for that law is because they can't vouch for the quality of the drugs? They haven't tested those drugs?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Exactly right. They haven't tested those drugs. That's what they say. We haven't tested those drugs, we don't know if they'll be good for you or not.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: But in a way, that's a legitimate thing. Like. In a way, you'd want the government to actually do that, to say, we have no idea if this manufacturer's reputable and the drug's OK.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Well, I would argue that I have the right to take that chance myself. We're just simply not allowed to do this. Now, we can bring in foreign-made food and foreign-made clothes and everything else, but we're not allowed to bring in foreign-made drugs because they are untested supposedly.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: There's a passage in your article where you say, "I can go to Europe and buy their wine for less, go to Asia and buy their clothes for less. American companies can buy their raw materials for less overseas, or they can move their operations abroad in order to hire cheaper labor or management. But on a mind-boggling reversal of the American principle of supply and demand, I cannot purchase cheaper drugs and bring them home."

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: That's right. And that's the part that, to this day, infuriates me, particularly about the new Medicare drug bill, which has expressly now, completely, clearly forbidden Americans to go overseas and bring back drugs for any reason whatsoever.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And so the FDA holds this stuff up. How long do they hold it?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: They held it for a couple of weeks. And for the first time, we'd cut his dose in half to try and eke it out, as the package wasn't delivered. Then we cut his dose in half again. Eventually it became clear to me that they were not going to give it to us for any reason whatsoever. And in fact, they were going to destroy it. And that's when I turned to my elected officials. I thought, well, maybe they can help me on this end. One senator, Barbara Boxer, was phenomenally helpful. Her office went to work on it. They just dug their teeth in and they had that package sprung in about 24 hours.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And did you end up having to get the senator's office to intervene for you again?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Yes, I did.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Like, every time it would come to the border, the same place, same people?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: No, eventually I figured out a method with the FDA guy that they were willing to accept. We had to provide these very elaborate excuses of why my father was using the foreign version versus the American version of this drug. We had to sort of basically manufacture excuses.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Oh, I see. You had to say that the American version didn't work?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Didn't work as well for my father for the following reasons, which we pretty much made up. It was pretty bogus, but they went for it. And they did that a few times. That system worked, and then it stopped working.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Why, what happened?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: At the end of 2002, we were bringing in another shipment and playing the game the way we'd learned to play it. And this time just couldn't get it sprung. And that was when I heard that the law, not that the law had changed, but that enforcement of the law had changed. And they were beginning to really crack down now on letting these drugs in.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: The FDA case officer suggested that I go to the US company that manufactured the drug and apply for patient financial assistance.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Now, that's a special program which lets you say, we don't have the money to pay the $47,000, so give us a break, basically, on humanitarian grounds?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: That's right. And apparently, a lot of the pharmaceutical companies have these things, whether people know it or not, for their more expensive drugs. And we had actually applied for this at the very beginning, when my father was first prescribed this drug, and he didn't pass. He wasn't poor enough, they thought, so I decided we'd just lie. And I called the patient financial assistance line. They had an 800 number. And I was trying to sort of suss them out on, like, how poor did you really have to be before they would accept you? And she said, well, I can't tell you that. But she did, I think inadvertently, admit the only thing I really needed to know, which was that they don't actually check anything you say on the application.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Oh, she said that to you straight out?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: She told me straight out. I felt like it was something, she went, oh God, I shouldn't have said that. And in my brain, a little bell just went off and I went, yes.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Now, a few months after your dad died-- and we should say that he didn't die of the cancer, he ended up dying of heart failure-- Congress passed the Medicare drug bill, which was designed to address exactly this problem. If your dad had survived, what would this bill have done for him, which is supposed to, basically, take these expensive drugs and put them within financial reach of people?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Well, I ran the numbers on it and I found that he would have still had to pay over $6,000 a year. And obviously, that's a lot cheaper. It's still not as cheap as the $1,200-a-year version you could get overseas.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So is that good or bad, as far as you're concerned, getting it down to $6,000 to--

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: It's not good enough. It's not good enough, in my opinion, not if the drug companies are going to be able to ask $47,000, in my father's case, for a drug that all the research and development was done more than 40 years ago. If they have the right to do that, then I think we need to have something. If the government's going to become the biggest drug buyer on the planet, then they need to do something about enacting price controls or setting standards that they're willing to pay.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: The thing you're talking about is actually that, under the bill, the United States government would not be able to negotiate for lower prices. They wouldn't be able to say, we're buying a huge quantity, so give us a price break?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: Right. Congress expressly forbade that in the Medicare drug bill.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And as you note in your article, when the government buys anything in quantity, they negotiate the price down.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: That's right. That's another case, I think, where the pharmaceutical industry wrote the law.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And do you blame the drug companies for that?

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: julia whitty
utterance: I blame the drug companies at getting through to our elected officials, yes. They're obviously phenomenally powerful, as we can see by the number of lobbyists that they employ: 600, more than one for every member of Congress. There's a personal lobbyist, in effect, for every member of Congress.

act_title: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Julia Whitty's story about getting her dad's $47,000 prescription filled is in the issue of Mother Jones. That is on newsstands now, and it's at motherjones.com.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Well, our program was produced today by Alex Blumberg and myself with Wendy Dorr, Diane Cook, Sarah Koenig, and Jane Golombisky, who is getting married today. Yes, today. We're going to have to call her Jane Feltes from now on. Our warmest wishes to her and to Rick.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our senior producer is Julie Snyder. Elizabeth Meister runs our website. Production help from Todd Bachmann and Kelsey Dilts.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our website, www.thisamericanlife.org, where you can listen to our programs for free. Or, if you care, you can buy CDs of them now. Well, you know, you can download audio of our show at audible.com/thisamericanlife, where they have public radio programs, bestselling books, even the New York Times, all at audible.com.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This American Life is distributed by Public Radio International.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: WBEZ management oversight by Torey Malatia. He came into the studio this week to watch us do the radio show. His review?

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: It was horrifying. It was the most upsetting thing I've ever seen.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: I'm Ira Glass, back next week with more stories of this American life.

speaker: davy rothbart
utterance: The room kind of started swirling around me and everything got really silent. You know, there's sort of, like, a roar fills your ears.

speaker: announcer
utterance: PRI, Public Radio International.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: Principal Gartner and Assistant Principal James have tried everything they know how to try. They've filed paperwork, they've talked to people above them. They've gotten the parents from their school to go and stand up at school board meetings. Nothing's worked.

ep-263.speaker: principal gartner
ep-263.utterance: We were told the new school would happen, this is about, six years ago.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: They run a public elementary school in Chicago called the Richard E. Byrd Community Academy. The school has no lunchroom, no auditorium, no gymnasium. Even for Chicago, it's pretty bad.

ep-263.speaker: cheryl james
ep-263.utterance: Promises were made. Land has been cleared. A sign has been posted for years and years and years. We have gone through planning, right down to picking out tile. And then, it's not happening.

ep-263.speaker: caprice
ep-263.utterance: There go our bullet hole in the window. There go our missing drinking fountain. And there go our other bullet hole in the window over there.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: Caprice, a fifth grader, takes on a tour of what's wrong with the building. Things were going nowhere in the campaign to get a new school until the fifth graders in her class, room 405, got involved this fall. Among the things that got them maddest about the school was the heating system. Here's Davielle.

ep-263.speaker: davielle
ep-263.utterance: At our classroom, I remember once the heat was supposed to be on but we had to put on our hats, our coats, our gloves. We put on our gloves, we can't even hardly write, because people have mittens. You know you can't write with no mittens.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: They walk me to the bathrooms. There's no soap, no paper towels, no paper towel dispensers. A door is missing from the stalls.

ep-263.speaker: davielle
ep-263.utterance: We don't have our own privacy. There aren't any doors on the stalls. And don't nobody uses the bathroom anymore. But--

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: So what does everybody do? You just hold it in?

ep-263.speaker: davielle
ep-263.utterance: Yeah, mhm. We go take it down to our lunchroom. It's a bootleg lunchroom. We've got a bootleg lunchroom, because it's a hallway with just tables in it.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: The bootleg lunchroom features bootleg cafeteria ladies, who look just like any cafeteria ladies anywhere, except they're serving chicken nuggets and corn and milk in the middle of the school hallway. The kids in room 405 decided that they needed a new school back in the fall when their teacher, Brian Schultz, a young idealistic teacher in his second year, decided to try something new, a program called Project Citizen, where the kids would pick some problem in the school or in their neighborhood that they wanted to solve. And then they would solve it together as a class. So one day Mr. Schultz stood at the board and had them name possible problems that they could address.

ep-263.speaker: mr. schultz
ep-263.utterance: Some of the problems that they came up with were everything from wanting to clean up litter in the parks to teenage pregnancy to stopping Michael Jackson.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: And did you try to get them to just choose one problem?

ep-263.speaker: mr. schultz
ep-263.utterance: That was the aim, was to pick one problem. And truly I thought that they would pick something like getting mandatory recess every day, or getting a different selection of drinks at lunch.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: But when the kids started naming their problems at their own school, he says, the feeling was so many of these problems could not be solved one by one. The only way to get an auditorium or a lunchroom would probably be just to build a whole new school, the one they were supposed to get six years ago, the one whose plans are actually on display in the entryway of this building for them to see as they walk in each morning.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: So that's what they decided to go for. They've had politicians visit. They've written letters to the head of Chicago schools. There have been TV crews. There's been coverage in the newspapers.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: But Byrd sits in the middle of Cabrini-Green, one of the most famous public housing complexes in the country. And the city of Chicago is tearing down the public housing high-rises around the school. Lots of Cabrini is already gone, replaced with expensive townhomes. Assistant Principal James says that maybe the new school will come only when this process is finished.

ep-263.speaker: cheryl james
ep-263.utterance: And maybe this is what's happening. Maybe the plan is to let's just stall it, stall it, stall it until the buildings are torn down and the new townhomes are all in place and we get the population we want for the new schools, but not for our students. It'll be for the new residents, because they're going to need a school.

ep-263.speaker: davielle
ep-263.utterance: I think they're going to fix stuff up. I don't really think they're going to give us a new school.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: Yeah? How come?

ep-263.speaker: davielle
ep-263.utterance: Because they're going to build condos over there. Because my mama said that when they knock down the projects, all the other people from them move over here, they're trying to make us move from over here.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: The kids are getting some small results. The school board has finally scheduled some repairs for the building, minor stuff, covering some fluorescent lights, fixing some wiring. If they just get repairs and not a whole school, a lot of kids say they're going to be really disappointed. And Principal Gartner is worried about the lesson that they're going to take away from all of this.

ep-263.speaker: joseph gartner
ep-263.utterance: If they don't see things happening, I'm afraid that they're going to say, mm hm, voice all you want, but your voice is a small voice and doesn't matter.

ep-263.speaker: ira glass
ep-263.utterance: And this is the problem with the big, desperate, brave attempt to change things. When you raise the stakes, you either win big or you lose big. And that's what our show is about today. From WBEZ Chicago, it's This American Life, distributed by Public Radio International. I'm Ira Glass.
